intro: Calyptridium nevadense, commonly known as the Sierra Valley goldenhead, is a flowering plant native to the western United States, particularly found in California and Nevada. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes mustard and cress plants, and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and basal rosette of leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes, showcasing adaptations to arid environments. Its botanical features include hairy stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves, which help reduce water loss in its native habitat.
